reviewText:
Lord of The Rings War in the North is surprisingly a very competent game. It cannot compete with the AAA titles with hand to hand combat and fantasy element, but it is good enough to be worth at least one play through. From the start it is evident that the developers put great effort into the game to make the environment shine with detail and realism. I was surprised to see such quality of level detail, despite the levels and gameplay being linear.

The character models and armor are very detailed as well. Every time you put newer more advanced pieces of armor it reflects on the model of your chosen character. Be it helmets, arm guards, leggings, body armor. All of it. It is also very accurate as far as movie content. Human, Elven, and Dwarven armor and items are what you'd have seen in the Lord of The Rings movies. It is not surprising since the publisher of the game is WB.

Positives written above do not come without the negatives. Nearly every level, no matter how spectacular in appearance, has plenty of invisible walls. These invisible barriers can be incredibly frustrating because often you'd find yoruself checking whether you can go in a particular path only to find that it is simply blocked by an invisible wall. As is the case with even the best games on the market, the level design becomes less impressive, and often shows plain lazyness as the player reaches the 2nd half of the game, and eventually the ending. Some areas start looking less detailed and more rushed. Invisible walls become bigger, lighting less consistent, etc.

War in The North also has issues with inventory organization. You may eventually gather enough weapons or armor to fill all the alloted slots in the inventory. Some items can be old, other items too high for current level, and there is no way to organize them. Neither manually nor automatically. You cannot select an item and move it in the inventory. Player just ha sto move the cursor over the items to see the stats of each.

Another rather inconvenient drawback is in the design of the game for those who want to play single player as opposed to 3 player coop. You have the option to give" your excess items or items meant for other two classes to your CPU controlled teammates. This is a very poor design gaffe because CPU does not  always equip the item gifted to them
date: nor compensate the party for the item value. Once it is given to a teammate controlled by the CPU the item is as good as gone.\nThis is not an issue if you play coop with 2 or three players. The other player actually gets the item and can use it. Similarly
recommended: when you play coop you can actually exchange items with each other to acquire complete sets of items meant to be worn together. They may be strangely acquired by your CPU partners
hoursPlayed: and when you switch characters between levels you may see the items that could complete your set on the other player you have picked to play as
voteText: but you are not able to either put it in any "shared chest" nor give to another player. Wasted opportunity.\n\nCombat is very satisfying and as the character levels up you have a wide choice of upgrades and moves and magic spells to pick from. The upgrade tree is very similar to that of Borderlands games in which you have three columns of skills which you invest points in to unlock the most powerful ones on the bottom. Once again
helpfulPercent: when you play single player you control your own player's upgrades
votesHelpful: but the CPU manages them automatically and utilizes them in hit and miss fashion. Sometimes you'll see the Lore Master (Elf lady) use some of her very helpful spells often
votesTotal: other times you won't. Thankfully you can switch to another character midgame to experience their gameplay style. Whatever you upgrade them with and equipment you give them will be present again if you select them in the future
votesFunny: but not when CPU controls them.\n\nThe plot and the story is ok. It is not very impressive
commentsCount: but should be interesting to any fan of Tolkien universe or the Peter Jackson movies. The events take place at the same time as the Lord of The Rings three books. You encounter some characters mentioned in the books
column16: get to visit iconic locations such as Lorien and get to talk to most of the main characters of LOTR. The cutscenes are very well animated
column17: most of the time. Some cutscenes are just cheap fill ins where characters just stand there. Characters are voiced by quality voice acting
column18: but unfortunately the same voice actors are recylced for many characters which feels very cheap. The main antagonist of the story does not impress too much because not much of their background or motivations are reveled to the player.\n\nThankfully and to benefit of those who just want to kill some orcs
column21: and whatever there is a survival mode available and at least 3 maps to play it on. You basically fight many waves of enemies. Pretty fun. After the main campaign is complete you are able to replay the game on Hero mode. This is actually pretty good because you can save up the "Gifts" that big characters give you upon completing their side quests. If you save the Gift for the Hero mode you will not get under powered items but instead get to choose a gift from high level items which goes all the way to level 40 or 50. Also replaying is fun if you play as one of other two characters. Each of them is fun to play because of pretty unique abilities and moves."

reviewText: There are times you want to play dungeon crawlers and you look to the online where you will rack and stack yourself at end game with specific builds, items, and do your research and reading.  There are other times you want the simple joy of killing a lot of creatures in a nicely themed area, with a mild bit of challenge, gear and leveling that is easily managed, and played with a friend or two.  This is a wonderful dungeon crawler to unwind to, and the kills are quite visceral (that awesome level of physics and gore that'd you'd expect when a goblin meets an axe wielded by a dwarf in combat).

reviewText: LOTR: WITN is an action game faithfully set it Middle Earth, with a story line that executes in parallel to the LOTR main canon.  One of Sauron's second in command is amassing a large army in the Northern reach near the Misty Mountains, and you and your companions are sent to investigate.  The fiction works well, and is told through excellent music and voice acting.  The bulk of the game consists of bashing and decapitating, which is also executed very well.  There are some RPG elements: skill trees, loot, enchanting and so forth... making wise choices for your character type will make battles much easier.  There is a co-op mode also which I intend to try.  If you are a LOTR fan you shoud DEFINITELY play through this one.

reviewText:
This is easily one of my favorite games.
Highly recomended for LOTR fans!

My only complain would be the faulty ingame voice chat that you cannot(or couldn't as I played it back in Nov 2013)disable. It was very laggy and when you wanted to use skype you got ghost voices all over the palce. Few ingame glitches, though so minor that they aren't even worth mentioning.

Entertaining combat and lots of good voice acted NPCs to talk to! The environment is superb, the locations bring nostalgia and the loading screens make you want to jump into a Tolkien book once more.

I recommend getting it on a sale and if you do - buy 2 extra copies an play with friends. It is not as enjoyable when you play solo due to the poor companion AI.

Overall I'd give it a solid 8/10 in CO-OP and a 6/10 when Soloing.

reviewText:
Honestly... The game could of been harder, people are saying it needs co-op... Honestly... That's what this game lacks. This was a big let down for me as I have played other LOTR games that were much better than this... It seems they whipped up the story line as fast as they could, the acting was horribly done and the story was far too breif. The action combat style of the game was the only thing good about it. However, the AI was dumber than previous LOTR games. I would of loved to give this game a great review, but it didn't quite reach my expectations as a LOTR game.

Sure you take a good amount of damage if you're hit, which is why people probably find this game moderatly hard, but honestly, that's all it was. They hit you hard, and harder on higher difficulties. The AI did not get smarter, just simply, your health pool took more damage. So if you know how to strike and move, this game is beyond easy...

So mainly what I'm disliking the game for is...

1. Dumb AI
2. Very breif storyline
3. Extremely easy
4. (Just throwing this out there) I expected more mobs. There wasn't that many to fight, and they came in small waves that were easily controlled.

What's good about the game?

1. Combat Style

reviewText:
As a casual Lord of the Rings fan, I found this game to be rather on the nose.  I'm going to list the good and the bad that I've encountered so far in a list of bullet points and then expand on them later so that it doesn't get too TL;DR.

GOOD:
*  Fun action gameplay
*  Interestingly well done facial models based off the actors from the movies - (though not mocapped or anything)
*  Decent amount of gameplay hours

BAD:
*  Terrible console port
*  No way to differentiate LAN from internet multiplayer (it does work with LAN, just doesn't give any network information)
*  Painful 'story' attempting to garner interest from the fanboys
*  Ugly, ugly graphics
*  Unimmersive sound
*  No way to toggle off voice chat

This game hurts to play.  It's an unpolished and lazy attempt to cash in on the success of the movie releases.  You play one of a party of 3 characters that spend the entire game one or two steps away from the ringbearers. One of the first areas is Bree, where you meet up with Aragorn who's waiting on Gandalf and Frodo.  After you finish the quest, they've made their way through the town.  We all know how the storyline of the novels runs and the constant Oh
date: you just missed the really cool characters but you helped them on their journey... I promise" gets boring quickly.\n\nIt is a poor console port.  The engine has not aged well
recommended: and it shows.  Despite the beautiful lands in LotR
hoursPlayed: the brown filter that is more commonly seen in FPSs makes the graphics look even worse than they actually are.  I am not someone that expects Crysis-like graphics in every video game
voteText: but this is painfully dated.  There is no way to change any networking settings (not that I expected them to be there) and this is a pain in the â™¥â™¥â™¥ on a PC release.  You can't specify whether to use LAN or WAN though it does appear to function on both.  There is no way to turn off the voice chat
helpfulPercent: and it is SO laggy.  Playing with my partner over LAN in the next room had a good 3000~ms latency on the VoiP.\n\nI love RPGs
votesHelpful: I love hack n slashers
votesTotal: and I quite enjoy the LotR story.  I can put up with bad writing if the gameplay is fun
votesFunny: and vice versa.  I've got countless hours wasted in these sorts of games.  Unfortunately
commentsCount: there isn't much substance to hold any interest in this game whatsoever
column16: and completely unimmersive.\n\nTL;DR.  Crap LotR action RPG that I'm glad I got in a Humble Bundle instead of paying full price.  Not even whacky co-op shenanigans could make this fun."

reviewText:
LOTR* game (What you are waiting for?)

This game is one of the best games from WB*(Other publishers: Interactive entertainment, Feral interactive) i have ever played. Games combat system is better than any other games what i have played. It is like you can`t slash the air. At this game you playing at same era than Aragorn, Legolas, Gimli, Frodo, Sam and going on. So this like side stuff for real lotr. You are playing with a Draf, Elf and Human. (you can change your character when you start game) You move from place to place whit map. and you have to defeat enemys from one place at once. Sometimes there is bosses. And this game obtains Co-Op so you can play with your friends.

I give this game 10

+Combat is one of the bests in the world of gaming
+Story is really good
+It is LOTR
+You can play with any sharacter you want. (Elf, Draf, Human)
+Co-op makes the game even better.

Games graphicks are not the best and there were some crashes. I dont care the game itself is awesome.

I recommend this game for you IF you like LOTR, adventure & actiongames.

*Lotr= Lord of the Rings
WB=Warner Bros

reviewText:
Disappointing. By a long shot. Firstly, the graphics are awful and the environment is boring. The story is bad too and the voice actors are a letdown as well. American accents in Middle-Earth? Sounds completely out of character. The dialogs are ridiculous...whoever wrote the game shouldn't get a job ever again.

The combat is quite fun but very repetitive. What I do like is the appearances of some of the little known creatures of Middle-Earth, e.g. Gwaihir and Radagast. The  upgradables are also fun.

It is definitely not a good game and I cannot really recommend it unless you are into the Tolkien-Universe and even then...

reviewText:
I came here to write a happy review but it will be short and angerd.

I realy enjoyed this game, decent hack&slash, decent story, decent graphics. A game great for looting with your best buddys. You can play 3 different classes and races for that. Ranger, Chapion and Lore-master, all having their own skill trees, their own weapons (just the bows and staf), their own special armoring. A little variaton of enemies but passable. Not even a shalow ARPG but fun no matter. Just don't buy it at full price, wait for it to be below normal summ.

I would recommend War in the North if only it had not crashed on my 2nd run trough it, at the very last chapter and guess what, it left me with no save files. That's right, it completely deleted my save game files. Afterwards I cheekt forums for answers and the game supposedly does that. When you might ask, when ever it feels like, so my hours spent enyoing War where completely wiped.
So, great time with the game, but specifically one little crash made me unlike this avareg but decent work. Because the rights has been sold from SnowblindStudios the game will not be patched and save files will be lost(mark my words). I do not recommend it, let it sit in the cold depths of forgoteness.

reviewText:
Performance of the game:
This game is a buggy mess.  I powered through a very bad bug in chapter 2 of the game that would have it randomly crash, took about 3 hours to pass a single section that should of took about 20 minutes, twice crashing seconds before triggering the saving in the game.

Most of the times it crashes it doesn't crash to desktop it blue screens my computer most of the time not giving a reason just something failed and the memory address of all â€œ0â€s and an x or 5 thrown in.

I have made it through chapter 7 with it crashing about every half hour and now in chapter 8 of the game I found another section that will crash every few minutes similar to chapter 2 of the game.  Now I have to quit.




The actual review of the game (based on when it is not crashing)
one of the first things you get is a bird friend and you hit the 4 button to call for his aid.  Well the Elf character has a power that has you block and hit 4 (holding CTRL then hit 4).  even though the 4 icon has changed from the bird logo to a different logo, BOTH powers are used; the bird and area heal.  I wasted a lot of bird power trying to keep the other 2 friends alive.


Defense missions are the worst part, it goes fine until the enemy brings in the giant troll and he walk past you not caring that you are attacking him and then kills the thing you are protecting in 15 seconds.

I personally am more of a dodger power and like to dodge and not much blocking, I would of liked a double dodge (I only played the elf so I do not know if the other characters have a double dodge).  After facing a double sword enemy who is stabbing you so much that you can not dodge, I have learned to block against them just be for they attack and then attack them back.

Dialog was interesting even had a few points that you could try to tell some one that we are just passing through this very remote area to get to grandma's house (not exactly G maâ€™s house, but you are lieing about what you are doing so I thought it appropriate) and the NPC has non of that, but a very interesting choice to tell them.  Also there is a lot of repeat dialog choices that are represented as new choices.  Example: someone tells you of a castle; new option of the castle in dialog choices, npc just repeats the thing that brought up the new choice.



Combat was fun and interesting, slowly adding in new enemies over the 6 chapter's I played.  I would of loved to see how the ending turned out and if they kept adding new enemies through the end, but sadly the bugs and crashing my computer is enough to make me stop.

reviewText:
If you read the top reviews for this game, you'll notice the good review, but there is a GOOD reason for the low metascore. The amazing reviews ons team are most likely because the only people who will buy this game are already avid LOTR fans. I however, was not a fan beforehand and will deliver a serious review.

Here's a complied list, and at the end of the list I'll let you be the judge of whether or not you wish to dive into this game

Is the story any good?
Absolutely, as any RPG you have the freedom to partake in the story or to skip it and get into the action. Talking to the villagers of every town will get you side quests in which you can earn some intense gear.

Is the combat any good?
Personally, the combat is pretty repetetive, but it does allow for some customizing, much like dragon age.

Is there customization?
The customization is limited but it IS there, which is better than no customization. Note: You may only customize AFTER starting the game.

Diversity?
Yes, you're able to pick one of the three heros and go along with it, there's also multiplayer functions so you can bring two friends and each have their own hero.

All of these things are good, so why is this a downvote?
There is only one bad quality, but you must realize the depth of the how terrible it is to understand why it's a thumbs down.

What is wrong with it?
The game crashes OFTEN. This game was released on Nov. 1, 2011 which wasn't too long ago. Yet, the game runs like it was made in 2002, with how the graphics are I originally thought this game was made in 2006.

My computer is really new, and it is capable of running Bioshock infinite on max settings, yet it cannot run LOTR War in the North for over an hour without crashing. What's more, is that it does not simply crash the game/window/application. It crashes the ENTIRE DESKTOP.

THIS IS WHY THE GAME RECIEVED A LOW METASCORE, IT IS INCREDIBLY UNSTABLE. It is borderline unplayable, because up until the undead level, you don't really have any problems with crashing. but the second you get to the undead mobs, the game cannot control it's own software and seeminglye xplodes upon itself. And, because the undead levels are canon, you MUST pass through them. I was lucky because my computer was new, so I had a long grace period before it killed itself, but any run of the mill computer may not be able to handle it at all.

All in all, this was a great game, if it wasn't so cancerous to it's own programming, I as a person who is not a die-hard fan of LOTR can honestly say this would have recieved an 85-95 score for what it brings to the table. However, an amazing game CANNOT HAVE A FOUNDATION MADE SUITABLE ONLY FOR GAMES 5 YEARS BEHIND ITS TIME.

reviewText:
I first bought this at Gamestop for my 360 to check it out and see if it was any good. I played previous SnowBlind games, but I'm not a Lord of the Rings fan at all. But what I played of the used copy convinced me to pay it forward so to speak. I went back to Gamestop and changed it in for a real copy and paid the exta money. I very much enjoyed the game when I played it on the 360. I thought the combat was fun as well as the archery. I don't play the mage class so I can't say anything about that. I enjoy open world games the best. Like The Elder Scrolls and Grand Theft Auto. Fallout and what not. This game gives a slight feeling of open world but it does give you direction. And people will like that also. Not knowing what to do in a game is not fun.

The difficulty seems fair. I'm not that great at video games, and found normal a fun, fair challenge.

I will soon find out if the xbox 360 controller works for this game. The controller worked fine! Nice.

So this is the 2nd time buying this game. Even though I played it twice on the 360. Warrior and Rouge class. Very fun.

I played co op with my cousin on Xbox Live. I think we played through the whole game. But I can't remember for sure. Very fun game to play with a friend.

It's fun co op or single player! I would give this game a try, It is not a masterpiece. The story pulled me in, even though I'm not a fan, and with the combination of great gameplay equals a great adventure!

reviewText:
Throwing rings into volcanoes is one thing, preventing nasty hordes of monsters from intervening with such activities is another. Intro music for our band of stalwart heroes, a human ranger, a dwarf fighter and an elven wizard(the only woman of course), who set out from the Prancing Pony at Bree, a place cursed with being drenched in perpetual rainy nights, after receiving instructions from non other than stapper, which is the Dutch translation for the nickname for Aragorn, who in this game looks remarkably like an actor called Viggo Mortensen.

The going is pretty unidirectional from the start. Stop the main bad guy AgandaÃ»r from intervening with the rest of the world by killing him dead until he is. Easy enough. In between Bree and AgandaÃ»r's grave you meet some critters that are in the way, but that is how this game should be. They consists of nasty orcs and goblins, undead, biggers orcs, very big trolls, a huge giant even, humans in all shapes and sizes, spiders small, large and very large and that is about it really.
At various moments you get helped by token people you can do well without. At least they don't die on you most of the time, which saves you from that headache. The coolest thing around is however the giant eagle friend your team gains, which gives a nice air asset that you can throw against some of the bigger nasties, provided they are in the open and you didn't waste your limited supply of airstrikes on something smaller.

Somewhere in between you make a stopover at Rivendell where you are briefed by someone who looks remarkably like the actor Hugo Weaving. Incidently Hugo doesn't even hush up the fact that Frodo has a powerful ring that needs to be destroyed. So far for secrecy.
You get to speak to other actors too, like Orlando Bloom, Ian Holm, John Rhys-Davies, Elijah Wood and Liv Tyler and yes by now you know the game takes its cues from the Peter Jackson movies. It isn't bad but it isn't very original either.

And that might be the overall theme of this game. It isn't really bad, but it isn't really good either.. It is okayies. A word I just invented for this purpose. For instance; to lengthen your game experience they threw in a truckload of containers for you to plunder. You have to loot them all cause that is the only way to get neat new gear and what you find is pretty random. So there you are, hero of the war of the north, defeater of many a container...for you destroy or open more caskets, caches, barrels and other containers than you ever want too, because you will not only need to find loot for your own character, but also for your ai buddies, who might have no use at all for that stuff as far as can be told, but maybe they do or at least you can sell the stuff so you buy better stuff for you own, but most of all because this game is meant to be a co-op and can't quite figure out that you play it as a single player or as a co-op.

Your ai buddies require some hand-holding for them not to be killed and if you are the elven maiden wizard it is doubly up to you to make sure that your ai buddies don't get killed, for the wizard biggest task is preventing the other two from turning into pin cushions.

The overwhelming sensation you get when proceeding through this game is: if they just had.. If they just had added some more variety. If they just had added some more ways to do the quests.. If they just had added some more options in character development. If they just had added some interesting side quests. If they had just added some meaning full conversations.

The biggest surprise is at the end when you discover that after all is said and done and the dead are buried and the living celebrate, you still are only halfway developed. And why? Cause you can then redo the whole game again on a higher difficulty level and gain more levels. Oh wow..

War in the North is amusing enough to do once, but it totally lacks the charm to play once more, even as a different character. It is after all only okayies

reviewText:
Lord of the Rings: War in the North is a hack-and-slash game. That's... it.

You control one of three characters with no personality or character development trying to chain as many finishers as possible, until you unlock Farin's Explosive Arrow and trivialize the game. Even the only vaguely challenging sections, which are the optional horde challenge maps. Along the way you will meet other fan-favorite characters such as the Fellowship, but then you will discover they have about as much relevance to you as this game does to Tolkein's legendarium. Sorry, Lord of the Rings fans.

Your mission is to go kill the leader of Sauron's forces in the North, Agandaur. He is pathetically easy, but it's worth it (?) to see the CGI animation that probably ate up 70% of the budget for this game.

The only way this game becomes decent is if you somehow game one, preferably two, friends into playing it with you. The time commitment shouldn't be that bad because the game is both easy and short. Playing with friends helps disguise some of the game's more egregious single-player faults, such as an incredibly limited inventory system, no ability to switch between characters on the fly (this requires you to completely reload the game), and the fact that some parts of the game are straight-up inaccessible without two or more players.

Fortunately the game isn't super glitchy (there are some glitches but reloading usually fixes it) or unplayable, and you'll probably unlock 95% of the achievements without even trying.

Sadly, War in the North failed to live up to any of its promise. It's not a HORRIBLE game by any means, but there are way better uses of your time.

reviewText:
Great game BUT... Lots of problems with freezing and crashing... many said it was due to the AMD drivers (the game publisher said also), but guess what... there are numerous others, with NVIDIA or other GPU and said the same thing.
When I got to the end of the game, in the castle, the game completely crashed.
So I decided to give my Intel GPU a run... with all the settings low, same thing... the game did not crash, but regular freezing was evident. This game is not optimised at all. Looking at the CPU cores, it only mastered one core...
A big disappointment that I had to finish the game on my Intel GPU because the developers couldn't get it right...

reviewText: This game was very appealing at first, although it is rather disapointing. Let's start with the good things. It has amazing graphics and kill 'mini cutscenes', and does have rather good combat. But, the voice acting is horrible! If you have scene the LOTR movies, the voice acting for Elrond is laughable. They even had the audacity to put really bad american voice actors in the game. LOTR is mainly british (based on the movies and the books) and yet they chose average sounding american voice actors for some roles. Also, the story is very bad, and isn't original at all, because you are directly connected to the fellowship. At least have a seperate storyline, but no, they have to come up with a completely unoriginal, boring storyline. Also, there is abosultely no character development, and I think that if it wasn't for the good gameplay, I would have quit this game. Don't waste your money buying this game. It ISN'T WORTH IT!

reviewText: When I recieved this game I was hecka excited. I had finished this game on my friend's Xbox 360 only months before and enjoyed playing it with him in Co-op mode. After finshing this game on my PC I realised how boring and repetitive the game really was. The game is not a free-roaming or exploring type. It restricts you to the very bone with it's story levels, which are the only things that you can actually do in this game. Sure, myself being a huge Tolkien fan should enjoy this game a lot, but the lore is barely touched on. There are refrencing to the movies and books but no huge give away of what the game/story is actually about to all new-comers. If your looking for a Middle-Earth game with heaps of lore and factual basings on Tolkien's work, please, please buy Shadow of Mordor. I did so on my Xbox One, and have to say, it's probably one of my favourite games of all time.

reviewText:
Everything about this game screams mediocre.  I'll break each aspect of the game down below:

Graphics - stuttering and muddy.  Everything is in dark earth tones for the most party and tends to becomes a black/brown blur.

Sound/music - For the most part this is the best part of the game, or at least the part that sucks the least

UI/Mechanics - The UI is horrible.  There's just no way to say it more clearly.  It is easily one of the worst parts of this game.  The levelling and talent trees are lackluster, the HUD during gameplay is incomprehensible, and the combat is sloppy.

Story - Yes, it's set in Middle-Earth, and they have gotten a lot of the names of people/places directly from the lore, but that doesn't make the story actually interesting.  Essentially, you are a small band of adventurers (a man, an elf and a dwarf, super original) that need to distract Sauron's forces from the ringbearer during the time of the LOTR trilogy.  Really, it's just a hack and slash-fest that is completely uninspired and boring.

reviewText: I like the game and the CoOp mode, but there's game killing issues with AMD cards that can't be fixed without rolling back to 12.6/8 which is a few years old at this point. There's also the very annoying issue of VoIP that can NEVER be turned off in the game settings. I either have to mute Teamspeak and use the games VoIP (Which is delayed and crackly) or deal with hearing double of everything.\n\nThe issue with AMD cards is in Chapter 2 and 8 it will literally crash your display drivers and cause network players to be kicked out. Which can be quite annoying while CoOping. I wouldn't mind it if I was doing single player but this issue really kills the fun of it. Great game, Terrible Engine.

reviewText:
As a casual Lord of the Rings fan, I found this game to be rather on the nose.  I'm going to list the good and the bad that I've encountered so far in a list of bullet points and then expand on them later so that it doesn't get too TL;DR.

GOOD:
*  Fun action gameplay
*  Interestingly well done facial models based off the actors from the movies - (though not mocapped or anything)
*  Decent amount of gameplay hours

BAD:
*  Terrible console port
*  No way to differentiate LAN from internet multiplayer (it does work with LAN, just doesn't give any network information)
*  Painful 'story' attempting to garner interest from the fanboys
*  Ugly, ugly graphics
*  Unimmersive sound
*  No way to toggle off voice chat

This game hurts to play.  It's an unpolished and lazy attempt to cash in on the success of the movie releases.  You play one of a party of 3 characters that spend the entire game one or two steps away from the ringbearers. One of the first areas is Bree, where you meet up with Aragorn who's waiting on Gandalf and Frodo.  After you finish the quest, they've made their way through the town.  We all know how the storyline of the novels runs and the constant Oh
date: you just missed the really cool characters but you helped them on their journey... I promise" gets boring quickly.\n\nIt is a poor console port.  The engine has not aged well
recommended: and it shows.  Despite the beautiful lands in LotR

You can't specify whether to use LAN or WAN though it does appear to function on both.  There is no way to turn off the voice chat

reviewText:
Co-Op was a major selling point for me on this game.  Co-Op DOES NOT work.  The game crashes and/or players are kicked relentlessly.  This game was not ready to be distributed.

Only buy if you like LOTR so much that you are willing to button mash, non-stop, by yourself with a bit of story to add some flavor.

[Edit]

After some more play time, I have also started running into the constant crashing.

This is another shameful use of a beloved license to facilitate a money grab from gamers.

reviewText: Gameplay itself is actually quite fun in co-op and the story is interesting (if not a little cliched), especially if you're a Tolkien fan. That said, there's several annoying bugs to be wary of. The game forces you to use Steam Voice in co-op, which is counter-intuitive in the likely scenario that you're already using a better form of voice communication. The game crashes frequently in graphically intensive situations, and this is a commonly reported issue for AMD card owners with post-HD5k era GPUs. The aggregate score of 66 seems fitting, as those looking for this type of game should enjoy it if they're willing to tolerate its issues. Get it when it's on sale.

reviewText:
haven't even played this game for a full hour and it crashed. now it crashes on startup.

the game itself is really dated though. clunky, terrible AI, item and inventory system. if you give items to your allies you'll never get them back.

combat is repetitive, but I suppose all hack-and-slashers are in the same boat. also i never got to use more than one power so they might be OK.

the UI looks as old as diablo 2, even though it's a recent game. graphics are old. story seems contrived, but you should figure as much.

don't waste your money no matter how good the sale is.
